Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the Development of Spatial Skills in South Korean children
Award.AbstractNarration:
Children's early spatial skills (i.e., various abilities that involve mentally representing and manipulating objects) relate to later school performance in the math and sciences and entry into STEM careers. Striking cross-national differences exist in children's math and science abilities, with children in South Korea ranking in the top 10 in both subject areas. Already by kindergarten, South Korean children outperform children from various countries on tasks of spatial skill. These findings suggest the Korean advantage in spatial skills, and later math and science, might be rooted in early home experiences. Research is limited and needed on the development of children's spatial skills in nations that rank in the top 10 in math and science. Such research can inform educational practices and policy aiming to promote STEM development in children. Therefore, this project will: 1) examine the spatial skills of South Korean 3- and 4-year olds by developing and adapting new measures and 2) investigate how children's home environments (e.g., spatial toys like blocks and puzzles) and interactions with their parents relate to these skills. The project will be conducted at Seoul National University, the most highly ranked research university in South Korea, in collaboration with Dr. Keumjoo Kwak, who has expertise in how parental practices and home environments affect Korean preschoolers' academic success.

South Korean children surpass U.S. children in STEM areas by 7 and 8 years. To date, STEM research on Korean children has focused on early number skills. However, there is a dearth of research on the development of Korean children's spatial skills, which may partially explain South Korean children's aptitude in STEM areas. The first aim is to describe individual differences in spatial skill among South Korean 3- and 4-year olds. The study will extend research to an understudied population, age, and domain of cognitive development foundational to STEM performance: spatial skills of mental translation, rotation, and so on. A second aim is to examine South Korean parents? spatial language and spatial activities with children (e.g., block play) and relate these practices to children's spatial skill. The project will develop and adapt a battery of spatial skill assessments for children; new measures and procedures for assessing parent-child interactions around spatial concepts; and measures of parents' attitudes and beliefs about STEM disciplines (through videorecorded interactions, questionnaires, direct assessments of children). Findings will advance knowledge on the practices that best promote the development of early spatial skills and performance in STEM areas.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) results revealed striking cross-national differences in adolescent math and science performance, with teenagers in many East Asian countries outperforming those in the United States. This East Asian advantage in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, & Mathematics) is observed even in younger elementary school children, suggesting that STEM differences may be rooted in divergent exposure to and experience with STEM-related concepts and activities prior to school entry.

Early spatial skill development is an area of STEM learning that is receiving increased attention. Spatial skills are various skills that involve perceiving spatial information (e.g., an object’s shape or relative location) and mentally and/or physically manipulating objects and people in space (e.g., as seen in puzzle play and navigation). Early spatial skill development is of particular interest because early spatial skills relate to later math and science performance. However, little is known about the development of these skills in East Asian countries. To address this knowledge gap, the current project investigated the spatial skills of South Korean 3- and 4-year-olds and the environmental factors hypothesized to support spatial skill development.

South Korea is one of several East Asian countries that are heavily invested in promoting STEM education and a strong STEM workforce. These efforts are reflected in the country’s high 2015 PISA results. South Korean teenagers ranked 6th and 10th on math and science, respectively, whereas U.S. teenagers ranked 38th and 24th, and even younger South Korean children surpass U.S. children in early math skills. Although spatial skills are foundational to math skills, few if any studies have examined the spatial skills of young South Korean children. The goal of this work was to provide insight into the developmental origins of spatial skills in South Korea.

Methods

The current study investigated South Korean 3- and 4-year-olds’ spatial skills in relation to parenting practices, home environment factors, and early experiences.

First, data were gathered on children’s spatial skills. Children were assessed on their: (1) mental rotation (i.e., a task in which children had to match a rotated image with another, and could only do so by mentally manipulating the images in their mind); (2) receptive and expressive spatial language (i.e., understanding and producing shape or spatial relational words and phrases); and (3) block construction (i.e., reproducing a 3-dimensional block design with an identical set of blocks). Data on children’s counting skills and knowledge of number sets were also obtained.

Next, data were gathered on parent-child interactions around spatial tasks. Parent-child dyads were videorecorded during four activities: reading a number book, reading an I-Spy book of shapes, using magnet shapes to create an image, and playing with plastic blocks. Coding of videos provided information on parents’ support of children’s spatial learning in the form of spatial language, gestures, and modeling.

Third, information on environmental supports for children’s spatial skills was gathered from parent surveys on: toys and play materials at home (including puzzles and blocks); frequencies that children played with different types of toys and materials; frequencies that family members engaged in specific play activities with children; frequencies of parent-child book-reading; usage of digital media by children and parents; parental beliefs on digital media usage in the home; children’s current and previous childcare arrangements; parental beliefs on the goal/purpose of childcare; and children’s out-of-school activities.

Finally, parents’ spatial skills and anxiety around spatial tasks were examined as potential predictors of parenting practices and children’s spatial skills.

Results & Future Directions

Even within this relatively homogenous South Korean sample, children varied substantially in their spatial skills. Children’s performance on different measures of spatial and math skill were related, suggesting that different tasks validly captured common abilities in spatial areas. Moreover, within the narrow age range tested, older children surpassed younger children on all tasks, highlighting this developmental period as one of rapid change in spatial skills.

Parents showed a wide range of spatial language and behaviors, and parents’ use of spatial language related to children’s use of spatial terms during interactions. Further, parental anxiety around their own performance on spatial tasks related negatively to children’s mental rotation performance. Follow-up analyses will investigate the full set of children’s early experiences in relation to different types of spatial and math skills. Currently, parents and children in the United States are being recruited to compare early spatial skill development across the two cultures.

This work fostered cross-national collaboration, providing opportunities for researchers in the United States and South Korea to co-author papers presented at scientific meetings. At an educational level, this work promises to advance an understanding of early STEM development – spatial skill development, in particular. Current and subsequent research will help inform the design of educational curricula and parents of the best practices to promote STEM aptitude in South Korean and U.S. children.
